DOC.HEAD: KGB Chief Says Sakharov Exile an `Injustice'
Eds: SUBS 8 grafs for 5-12 pvs bgng `Sakharov, winner...' to ADD dates of exile, meaning of KGB; pickup graf 13 `Kryuchkov...'
DOC.TEXT: KGB chief Vladimir A. Kryuchkov said Tuesday it was an ``injustice'' to exile Andrei D. Sakharov to Gorky for nearly seven years _ a period of physical hardship and KGB harassment for the late human rights activist. In a wide-ranging news conference with a group of female journalists, the KGB head also predicted Soviets will be less fearful of his agency after new laws are passed defining its actions in investigations, including the use of informers and wiretaps. ``I think criminals should be scared of the KGB but innocent people shouldn't,'' he said. But he acknowledged ``there is reason'' for ordinary citizens to be scared after years of repression of supposed internal enemies. ``I think that when we pass a law on the KGB, it will do a lot to calm the situation,'' Kryuchkov said. Sakharov, winner of the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize for his protests of human rights violations in the Soviet Union, was buried Monday with the pomp and respect due a national hero, three years after he was released from his exile of January 1980-December 1986. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and half the Politburo attended a memorial service. Kruchkov was not among them. Many mourners blamed the KGB for Sakharov's poor health. Sakharov, 68, had been drugged and force-fed during a hunger strike while in Gorky, and a doctor warned him, ``We won't let you die, but we will make you an invalid.'' Kryuchkov on Tuesday said, ``Our activities should be aimed at defending human rights.'' Of the treatment given Sakharov, he said ``it was an injustice.'' Still, the amiable KGB chief's line was not quite consistent. In written answers to questions, he said, ``We have tightened requirements for observation of laws,'' and ``alternative applications'' of laws have been eliminated. Yet in verbal responses, he exonerated previous KGB administrations and much of his current staff. ``The law was imperfect, but people were abiding by it,'' he said. Security forces, he said in another statement, ``fought not against different-mindedness but against specific illegal acts.'' Thousands of Soviets were imprisoned for their political beliefs under a law banning ill-defined ``anti-Soviet activities.'' The law was rescinded last spring. The three-hour meeting with Kryuchkov was the latest sign of the KGB's greater attention to its image, both at home and aboard. He met the journalists at KGB headquarters in downtown Moscow, a site that still strikes fear into many Soviets. KGB stands for ``Committee for State Security.'' Kryuchkov, a member of the Communist Party's ruling Politburo, also gave a clear indication that the leadership is leaning toward acceptance of Sakharov's last call, a demand for removal from the Constitution of Article 6, which guarantees the party's monopoly on power. ``There is nothing eternal under the sun,'' he said. ``I'm talking about politics. The leadership is not going to hold onto Article 6.'' ``If our Congress decides to abolish or leave out this article, there will be no tragedy,'' he said. The Congress of People's Deputies heeded arguments from Gorbachev and voted 1,139 to 839 last week against placing the issue on the agenda of its current session. Only months ago, Sakharov was one of the few Soviets who dared mention the question publicly. But as one country after another in Eastern Europe abolished similar provisions under pressure of massive demonstrations and strikes, Gorbachev's position has softened. The Lithuanian parliament voted two weeks ago to eliminate a similar article from its constitution and substitute a multiparty system. The KGB chief noted the Constitution now treats the Communist Party as the leading organization, ``though it may not be true.'' He predicted the party would have to fight for its position in the future. Later, he added, ``We are analyzing what is going on in Eastern Europe. We are trying to learn from these mistakes and from these events.''
